---

---

<p>Translating the website via Drupal's interface is fairly intuitive. The following are some screenshots to guide translators through the interface.</p>
<p>Assuming one has translation privileges, at the top of the page below the page title is a series of tabs. <strong>Do NOT click on the Edit tab</strong> <strong>EVER</strong>. Click on the <strong>Translate</strong> tab to be taken to the translation page. If there is not a <strong>Translate</strong> tab, you either do not have translation privileges or the page was marked as non-translatable by the administrators.</p>
<p><img alt="" src="data:image/png;base64,"></p>
<p>In the situation where there is not any translations of a page yet, the <strong>add translation</strong> link will appear. If there is already a translation for a specific language, the <strong>edit</strong> link will be present.</p>
<p><img alt="" src="data:image/png;base64,"></p>
<p>Click on the <strong>add translation</strong> link to add a new page. This will bring the translator to an editor that has a copy of the current text but other settings predefined to the selected language.</p>
<p>Note that any translator who does not follow these instructions and ends up breaking the main English source will see their translation privileges revoked until they pass a test to demonstrate proper translation knowledge.</p>
<p>Menu translations work much the same way. You go to the primary English menu item and choose the translate button. Note that you <strong>NEVER</strong> add a new menu link when doing translations.</p>
<p><img alt="Image" class="imgp_img" src="/sites/default/files/imagepicker/4801/TranslateMenu1.png" height="112" width="811"></p>
<p>From there, you can either edit an existing translation or add a translation if there is not one.</p>
<p><img alt="Image" class="imgp_img" src="/sites/default/files/imagepicker/4801/TranslateMenu2.png" height="506" width="807"></p>
